description: From ethic +‎ -al, from Late Latin ethicus (“moral, ethical”), from Ancient Greek ἠθικός (ēthikós, “of or for morals, moral, expressing character”), from ἦθος (êthos, “character, moral nature”).

adjectives.description: ethical (comparative more ethical, superlative most ethical)

entries.meaning: (philosophy, not comparable) Of or relating to the study of ethics.
examples: The philosopher Kant is particularly known for his ethical writings.

entries.meaning: (not comparable) Of or relating to the accepted principles of right and wrong, especially those of some organization or profession.
examples: All employees must familiarize themselves with our ethical guidelines.
We are trying to decide what the most ethical course of action would be.

entries.meaning: (of a drug, not comparable) Only dispensed on the prescription of a physician.
examples: In most jurisdictions, morphine is classified as an ethical drug.

entries.meaning: An ethical drug, one only dispensed on the prescription of a physician.
